newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Baht speculators did not necessarily win - traders.
newsitem.headline: Baht speculators did not necessarily win - traders.

text.p: The dramatic de facto devaluation of the Thai baht on Wednesday was not necessarily a victory by speculators against the currency, as some media reports have suggested, traders said.
"There were a lot of short (positions) in the market at the end of May, but a lot of them gave up, covered their positions and slunk off," one trader at a European bank said on Thursday.
"Sure, there were people that made money, but overall I would say there's no way the speculators won," he added.

Towards the end of May speculators launched a huge attack against the baht. They aggressively shorted the currency -- that is, sold baht they did not have in anticipation of buying them back at a lower rate later.
The Bank of Thailand saw off the initial attack but was then faced with speculators who had shorted the currency in the forward market -- the market for baht for delivery in up to a year's time.
International financier George Soros has been tipped in press stories as being a potential winner in the baht devaluation stakes. But traders tend to dispute this.

"I've read the reports that Soros was short four yards (US$4 billion) in the forwards. Nonsense. He may have been short quite an amount, but you can't really hide a $4 billion position. We'd have seen him doing it and we didn't," the head of Treasury at a European investment bank said.

Soros himself declined to comment to Reuters on Wednesday on the baht devaluation but in an interview he did say: "I don't want to comment on the baht because we've been attacked by the Thai government and there have been some exaggerated rumours."

The traders said the timing of the Bank of Thailand's de facto devaluation -- which it engineered via a "managed float" -- was probably very much tied to the number of speculators left with short baht forward positions.

The head of Treasury said: "The Bank had done all the hard work seeing the speculators off in May. I'm sure they wouldn't throw in the towel and hand money on a plate to a load of short speculators six weeks later.
"My conclusion is that they waited for the bulk of speculators to bail out of their own accord -- these positions are pricey to run, you know -- and then do the sensible thing and devalue," he added.

Another trader at a U.S. firm concurred. "The Bank of Thailand lost four billion dollars of foreign exchange reserves in May. The last thing they'd want to have done is to let the speculators win," he said.
"I reckon they waited for the bulk of positions to be closed off, but this is only my guess. August will be very interesting," he added.
Towards the end of August, any three-month positions established at the time of the initial speculative attack on the baht in May will unwind.
